intro: Crusea cruciata var. villosior, commonly known as the hairy crucifix, is a flowering plant characterized by its distinctive cruciform (cross-shaped) flowers. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The leaves are typically hairy, giving the plant its varietal name "villosior," meaning "more hairy" in Latin. The plant is native to regions of Europe and parts of Asia, often found in dry, rocky habitats. Its flowers are usually pale yellow or greenish-white, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds.
